fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: We construct the additon by perform induction over the second variable n. That is, to construct an element m:\mathbb {N} \vdash \text {add}_\mathbb {N}(m):\mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N} The context \Gamma \equiv m:\mathbb {N} is fixed. Therefore we need to construct: \begin {align*} \Gamma &\vdash \text {add-zero}_\mathbb {N}(m):\mathbb {N} \\ \Gamma &\vdash \text {add-succ}_\mathbb {N}(m):\mathbb {N}\to \mathbb {N} \end {align*} The \text {add-zero}_\mathbb {N} is defined to be identity function trivially. To see how \text {add-succ}_\mathbb {N} is defined, we need to perform induction: \begin {align*} \text {add}_\mathbb {N}(m, \text {succ}(n))&\equiv \text {ind}_\mathbb {N}(\text {add-zero}_\mathbb {N}(m), \text {add-succ}_\mathbb {N}(m), \text {succ}(n)) \\ &\equiv \text {add-succ}_\mathbb {N}(m,n, \text {add}_\mathbb {N}(m,n)) \\ &\equiv \text {succ}(\text {add}_\mathbb {N}(m,n)) \end {align*} Hence \text {add-succ}_\mathbb {N} is defined as: \text {add-succ}_\mathbb {N}(m,n,x) \equiv \text {succ}(x) A formal construction of \text {add-succ}_\mathbb {N} is as follows: \dfrac { \dfrac { \dfrac { \dfrac {}{\vdash \mathbb {N}\space \text {type}} \quad \dfrac { \dfrac {}{\vdash \mathbb {N}\space \text {type}} \quad \dfrac {}{\vdash \text {succ}:\mathbb {N}\to \mathbb {N}} }{ n:\mathbb {N}\vdash \text {succ}:\mathbb {N}\to \mathbb {N} } }{ m:\mathbb {N}, n:\mathbb {N}\vdash \text {succ}:\mathbb {N}\to \mathbb {N} } }{ m:\mathbb {N}\vdash \lambda n.\text {succ} : \mathbb {N}\to (\mathbb {N}\to \mathbb {N}) } }{ m:\mathbb {N}\vdash \text {add-succ}_\mathbb {N}(m):\equiv \lambda m.\text {succ} : \mathbb {N}\to (\mathbb {N}\to \mathbb {N}) }\text {Block-1} Finally we combine the derivation together: \dfrac { \dfrac { \dfrac { \dfrac { \vdash \mathbb {N}\space \text {type} }{ m:\mathbb {N}\vdash m:\mathbb {N} } }{ m:\mathbb {N}\vdash \text {add-zero}_\mathbb {N}(m):\equiv m:\mathbb {N} } \quad \dfrac {\text {Block-1}}{ m:\mathbb {N}\vdash \text {add-succ}_\mathbb {N}(m):\mathbb {N}\to (\mathbb {N}\to \mathbb {N}) } }{ m:\mathbb {N}\vdash \text {ind}_\mathbb {N} (\text {add-zero}_\mathbb {N}(m), \text {add-succ}_\mathbb {N}(m)):\mathbb {N}\to \mathbb {N} } }{ m:\mathbb {N}\vdash \text {add}_\mathbb {N}(m):\equiv \text {ind}_\mathbb {N} (\text {add-zero}_\mathbb {N}(m), \text {add-succ}_\mathbb {N}(m)):\mathbb {N}\to \mathbb {N} }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We define addition over \mathbb {N} using the type theoretical induction principle of \mathbb {N}. \text {add}_\mathbb {N} : \mathbb {N} \to (\mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N}) which satisfies the following specification: \begin {align*} \text {add}_\mathbb {N}(n, 0)&:\equiv n \\ \text {add}_\mathbb {N}(m,\text {succ}(n))&:\equiv \text {succ}(\text {add}_\mathbb {N}(m,n)) \end {align*} abbreviated as m + n for \text {add}_\mathbb {N}(m,n).
